bibl.title: Letter from Jefferson Randolph Kean to Mrs. Mason Young, July 12, 1899

div1.p: Kean discusses the mystery of yellow fever, its effects and spread. He comments the state of sanitary conditions at the newly built Camp Columbia.

div1.head: Letter from Jefferson Randolph Kean to Mrs. Mason Young, July 12, 1899
div1.opener:
Chief Surgeon's Office.
HEADQUARTERS SEVENTH ARMY CORPS.
Gen Lee's
Quemados Cuba
July 12 99
My dearest Mummy
div1.p:
I have a feeling in
my inner consciousness that
I have been very remiss to
the best of grans in not
answering promptly and at
length your lovely letter of
about June 20th I send
a preliminary note as the
diplomats say but have not
yet got around to a regular
letter- This morning things
seen to be propitious. I am
shaved and dressed by seven
and am the only one up
except Martha who is
flourishing around in her
nighty in the bed room and
is up to all sorts of mis-
chief I have no doubt.
The little madre is sleeping
on both ears, and will not
appear for an hour yet-
The mornings here are really
delightful and I enjoy them
very much- It has been so
long since I have had
either the time or the access
to books & journals so as to
be able to do any profes-
sional reading that I devote
my mornings before breakfast
to my medical journals
and take great delight in
it. As yet I have no profes-
sional books here but hope
in the fullness of time to
get some from my friend
the S.G- was not the death
of Clendenin a shock to you
we felt it very much and
have been so anxious to hear
something of Mrs Clendenin but without result as
yet. The Santiago outbreak has given me
much food for thought, and I am now
resigned and willing for the girls to go north
at the end of this month- You see at Santiago
they had every advantage - a year's possession
of the town, abundance of money & greatest
of all a broad intelligent Dept. Commander
in Wood & one with the professional knowl-
edge to know what to do- And he did
a good job I have no doubt, yet in due
time along comes Yellow Jack and all
they could do was to take to the woods-
It is curious that Wood with his broad
and scientific methods should have got
the first turn-down while Ludlow with
his electrozone, and my chief who is
blinder than a blue-eyed cat to sanitary
necessities, should have easy sailing-
It all shows how little is yet know of
this mysterious disease- However yellow
fever does not worry me one half so
much as that pest of camps typhoid-
But Gen. Brooke unfortunately is just the
other way and as he runs this depart-
ment as if it were a small post and
allows Gen. Lee no freedom of action
whatever, you can see that my power
of effecting any good is small indeed-
Chief Surgeon's Office.
HEADQUARTERS SEVENTH ARMY CORPS.
It is especially so now as
I have again offended
his nibs, by being one of a
board of officers to exam-
ine the new barracks at
Camp Columbia- We handled
the stupid sanitary defects
& the parsimony where they
should have been generous
without gloves, & old B, is
wild with rage- He wrote
to Gen. Lee that we showed
ignorance, impracticability
& insubordination- They
in an official paper con
stitute my strong language.
The General wrote back that
we showed nothing of the
sort - that he had examined
the Barracks and every
word was true etc-

In spite of sanitary arrange-
ments which are simply
deadly Gen. Lee is ordered
to put his troops in them
at once. I have protested
against his doing so until
the defects are remedied-
It is a pretty fight!

As an example of their stupid-
ity the porches are built
in this climate without roofs
in order to save a little
sheet iron roofing- On the
other hand they have revol-
ving doors every 15 feet
which cost $46 dollars a piece
& are worth about $8-

You see Mums - (as Dr. Shine
used to call you) you always
take such interest or appear
to take it, in the matters that
I am interested in, that you bring down on
your head torrents of shop like this-
Louise vows that I have talked nothing
but sewers for three months- Well
thank Heaven I have won that fight
and am much indebted to Col. Black
for backing me up with his professional
opinion- I am that grateful that I
will give him an electrozone certificate
if he asks for it-

You will of course know before this reaches
you of poor Woodruffs death of Yellow
Fever- How fatal it has been among the
officers. I have not heard yet of any
who has recovered- Poor Mrs. Woodruff
do you remember how she carried on about
this war- He always looked to me as
if his kidneys were not sound, and
in yellow fever the only hope is in their
activity- I have not had a line from
Liggett & dont ever know where he
is stationed-

Here is Martha to go with me to the
P. O. & get this into the 8 oclock mail
bag- She sends her love to gran &
says “tell her I love her so much”- Love to
the girls & Mrs. Y.
